blocks.value: In the Gospel of John, Bartholomew is called Nathaniel. He was one of the first disciples of Jesus Christ. He was introduced to Jesus by Philip. According to an account in the Gospel of John, when Philip first told Nathaniel about Jesus, Nathaniel was skeptical. He said, "Can anything good come from Nazareth?" Nazareth was a small village with an insignificant reputation.

Upon meeting Jesus, Nathaniel's skepticism would quickly be shown for its falsity. Jesus said to him "Here is a true Israelite in whom there is nothing false." Nathaniel responded "How do you know me?" Jesus answered, "I saw you while you were still under the fig tree before Philip called you." Nathaniel then responded "Rabbi, you are the Son of God; you are the King of Israel."

Legend indicates Bartholomew traveled to India, with St. Thomas, where he taught the gospel. He then went to Greater Armenia to preach. He is said to have been flayed and crucified by King Astyages of Armenia for converting the king's brother, Polymius. This legend says King Astyages was furious and ordered Bartholomew's execution.
